Elliotte Rusty Harold wrote:

> Sometimes we do need subclassing and extra extension points, but not
> that many and not that often; even when considering only the most
> abstractly inclined of programmers. Extension points are not without
> cost. There's is or should be a significant hurdle to be jumped before
> adding a new published method. Even if the method is inherently useful
> and has no corresponding problems, it still needs to be useful enough.
> It's not enough that one or a few people might use a method. It needs to
> be pretty clear that large percentage of a library's users are going to
> take advantage of the feature, or that it be extremely important to a
> smaller but still sizeable percentage.
>
Elliotte,

I had promised not to post on this topic again, but I'm still genuinely 
curious: is there not room, in your opinion, for a third option between 
"totally public: published and documented for all the world to use in 
safety", and "totally private: utterly hidden, technically enforced to 
be available only to the code publisher"?  I've found a use for this 
middle way.  As a framework user, I've been grateful it was there.  As a 
developer, I've sometimes opted for the "totally public" when the 
"totally private" was obviously wrong, but found I've wasted time on 
documentation and finalizing design for a feature that only a few people 
use, and used wonderfully.

    David Saff
